column4: i am running a harddrive check atm and during this my system is / partition gets full because /var/www/messages|kern.log|syslog is about 30gb. is there a way to disable logging?
delete the logfile, most programs that create logs, only append to existing files, and if the file doesnt exist, then logging = disabled. Im 90% sure klog operates like this

i did via console and "rm". but i recreated them and set the proper permissions. the wired thing is that "df" shows that there is still no free space. and i am sure i delete the right files ;) "baobab" clearly showed it
are you out of inodes? `df -i`
then something is using your diskspace, du program can be used to find out what is taking up so much space

yeah. but i am using the gui application "baobob". its default in ubuntu and it showed me the huge 3 log files before. the wired thing is that baobob shows that there should be plenty of space but df shows its full. and the system feels as it is full. firefox is a pain currently. all at slowmotion. but the cpu is only at 20%
I dont trus baobob, use du please
ok. mom
how do i limit the output to just show the files over ... lets say ... 1gb?
use sort to list by size, something like this du -chs * | sort -n
actually to revers sort by size this is ideal du -cs * | sort -nr
wired. http://pastebin.com/9XpmweD7
run a filesystem check
i am doing this with another drive, which imho makes the logs go crazy and using up all space. besides this, its about my / partition. i need to umount it check the fs, right?
yes, you cant check a mounted filesystem, you can `sudo touch /forcefsck` and reboot
thanks. can i abort an filesystem check when its currently searching for bad blocks?
are you doing a filesystem check on / now?
no. another drive. no system partition... an old storage drive.
yes you can cancel it
dmesg | tail works. there is always a fresh output about drive errors of the drive i am currently checking. where does this data come from? i mean it has to be read somewhere
the data dmesg outputs is generated by the kernel using the function printk()
